attributes.action: address the 4.5 million "fuel poor" households and look at the profit made by the energy industry
attributes.action_prefix: We the undersigned petition the Prime Minister to
attributes.background:
An estimated 4.5 million households now fall into the category of being fuel poor, the National Energy Action group (NEA) claimed.

Speaking at a Business and Enterprise Select Committee hearing in Westminster, Jenny Saunders, the NEA's acting chief executive said this "dramatic increase" was due in part to a rise in fuel prices.

Those suffering most from the increases were those on pre-pay meters who were paying more for their fuel bills than customers paying by direct debit, Ms Saunders said.

Ms Jennings argued that customers paying by direct debit tended to be more affluent whereas those paying via prepayment were sometimes on lower incomes and were using the prepayment system as a means to aid budgeting.

The government has set targets to remove vulnerable people from fuel poverty by 2010, and all households in England by 2016, but Ms Jennings said that these targets "could not be met".
